data.title: The Church of St Mary the Virgin, Fordwich (nr. Canterbury), Kent, England
data.meta_description: This now redundant medieval church dates from the Norman era. There is some Saxon material in the nave. The chancel and north aisle were added in the 12th century. During the following century, the chancel was extended and the west tower was built. In the 14th century, the windows in the south wall of the church were inserted. Box pews were added to the interior in the 18th century, and the church was floored with tiles. The church closed in 1995, and was vested in the Churches Conservation Trust on 5 December 1996.
data.text: This now redundant medieval church dates from the Norman era. There is some Saxon material in the nave. The chancel and north aisle were added in the 12th century. During the following century, the chancel was extended and the west tower was built. In the 14th century, the windows in the south wall of the church were inserted. Box pews were added to the interior in the 18th century, and the church was floored with tiles. The church closed in 1995, and was vested in the Churches Conservation Trust on 5 December 1996.
